required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Self-Selection and Actual Use Trial of Ibuprofen 600 mg Immediate Release/Extended Caplet
clinical_study.official_title: Ibuprofen 600 mg Immediate Release/Extended Release (IR/ER) Caplet Self-Selection, Safety and Compliance Study

oversight_info.authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

brief_summary.textblock: A self-selection and actual use trial to evaluate the extent to which consumers will appropriately select and use the 600 mg immediate release/extended release caplets and comply with dosing instructions.

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Safety Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.measure: Self-Selection Arm: Percentage of participants who either correctly select to use or correctly de-select not to use the 600 mg IR/ER product, based on typical duration of pain.
primary_outcome.description: Among those who select the 600 mg IR/ER product, the percentage of subjects who report their typical duration of pain, if left untreated, to be greater than or equal to 6 hours, will be considered to have corectly self-selected. Likewise, among those who do not select the 600 mg product who report their typical duration of pain, if left untreated, to be less than 6 hours will be considered to have correctly de-selected the IR/ER product.

primary_outcome.measure: Compliance Arm: Percentage of participants who use the product for more than 10 days (not necessarily consecutive) during the study and have an average daily dose of greater than 1600 mg.
primary_outcome.description: Excessive use of the product is defined as: (1) Using the product for more than 10 days (not necessarily consecutive) during the study and having an average daily dose greater than 1600 mg OR (2) Using the product for 10 days or less during the study, taking more than 20 caplets and having an average daily dose greater than 1600 mg.

primary_outcome.measure: Compliance Arm: Percentage of participants who use the product for 10 days or less during the study, take more than 20 caplets and have an average daily dose of greater than 1600 mg.
primary_outcome.description: Excessive use of the product is defined as: (1) Using the product for more than 10 days (not necessarily consecutive) during the study and having an average daily dose greater than 1600 mg OR (2) Using the product for 10 days or less during the study, taking more than 20 caplets and having an average daily dose greater than 1600 mg.

secondary_outcome.measure: Dosing patterns among subjects who use the product excessively.
Dosing patterns among subjects who are inappropriate self-selectors.
Dosing patterns related to exceeding 1200 mg/day.
Dosing paterns related to exceeding 600 mg/dose.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Ibuprofen 600 mg Immediate Release/Extended Release Caplet

intervention.intervention_name: Ibuprofen 600 mg Immediate Release/Extended Release Caplet
intervention.description: Ibuprofen 600 mg Immediate Release/Extended Release Caplet to be adminstered orally (i.e., one caplet every 12 hours, not to exceed 2 caplets per day) for pain.
intervention.arm_group_label: Ibuprofen 600 mg Immediate Release/Extended Release Caplet

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- at least 12 years of age
- use of at least 5 doses per month of over-the-counter pain relievers over the past 3 months
- provide written informed consent (subjects 12-<18 years of age provide a written assent and parent/guardian will provide written informed consent)
- capable of and willing to swallow the study medication
Exclusion Criteria:
- participated in other research studies in the last 6 months
- they or someone else in their household work for a pharmaceutical company, is a relative of study site personnel involved with the study, or an immediate family member is already enrolled in the study
- have a history of known allergies to ibuprofen, aspirin, or other NSAIDs
- have a history of heart surgery in the last 60 days or planned heart surgery in the next 60 days
- female subjects are pregnant or breast feeding
